commentary_central: The Fed is unlikely to cut in July as it waits for a few months of good inflation data before considering a cut.
commentary_higher: While the possibility of a raise was discussed in the May FOMC minutes, the consensus is still that this is very unlikely. The Fed would have to see a sharp re-acceleration of inflation for this to become likely.
commentary_lower: Very sharp fall in employment, concurrent with rapid disinflation in both June and July CPI.

commentary_central: Good inflation data continues
commentary_higher: Re-acceleration of inflation and tightening of labour market.
commentary_lower: Very sharp fall in employment, concurrent with rapid disinflation in both June and July CPI.

commentary_central: Disinflation does kick in, but with a slight lag
commentary_higher: US private demand remains resilient, labour market stays tight , policy error
commentary_lower: Cliff-edge transmission leading to suddenly weaker demand and rapid disinflation; Global disinflation from supply-side shock

commentary_central: The Fed continues its gradual accommodation of monetary policy through the early days of the new administration, seeking to achieve a neutral interest rate by year end. It says policy is no longer significantly restrictive.
commentary_higher: Concerns about remaining inflationary pressure, a new administrationâ€™s loose fiscal policy and international supply shocks prevent the Fed from removing its restrictive stance of policy.
commentary_lower: Interest rates are cut rapidly as the economy continues to weaken forcing the Fed to move towards a stimulative position again.

commentary_central: The Fed hails its achievement of a neutral rate of interest in a relatively stable US economic environment
commentary_higher: Higher interest rates are required as a result of excess demand, supply shocks and evidence that the neutral rate was higher than previously thought
commentary_lower: Persistent weakness in the economy forces the Fed into a looser stance amid accusations it held rates too high for too long

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the long term trend growth of the US economy plus inflation, although the path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario.
commentary_higher: Strong growth or a growing lack of confidence in US public finances requires a higher neutral interest rate. Strong growth because plentiful potential alternative investments allows savers to demand higher returns and weak public finances because government needs to attract more savings.
commentary_lower: Weak growth and persistently low generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: Our view has changed since our last round of projections in May. We now think the ECB will hold in July rather than cut for a second consecutive meeting. This is following an upward revision to the ECB's inflation forecast and higher than expected realised inflation in May & wage growth for Q1. The data dependent ECB thus moves more slowly than previously thought.
commentary_higher: Wage growth accelerates strongly, and household demand picks up substantially, causing an embarassing return to higher rates.
commentary_lower: Sudden weakness in economic activity forces the ECB to rip up previous plans and sharply reduce rates in July

commentary_central: We expect the ECB will cut at their September alongside a refreshed staff forecast which reiterates the view that inflation, while still above target, is moderating to 2 per cent gradually.
commentary_higher: Wage, inflation and productivity data do not improve sufficiently for the ECB to justify another cut in rates
commentary_lower: Sudden weakness in economic activity & reducing in inflation forces the ECB to rip up previous plans and sharply reduce rates in July

commentary_central: We expect the ECB to cut twice more by the end of the year, bringing the deposit rate down by 3.25%. Inflation is still expected to be above target by this point (forecasted to be 2.6%), economic growth and labour markets have been more resilient than expected, but the ECB will proceed as it remains comfortable in its inflation forecast (conditioned on market expectations of 3 cuts total in 2024) showing inflation falling back to about target reduction in 2025.
commentary_higher: ECB policymakers move slower on fears of insufficient progress on inflation or excessive exchange rate market reaction to earlier cuts
commentary_lower: Euro area activity slows down significantly further because of weakening demand

commentary_central: The ECB continues to cautiously reduce rates towards neutral in the first half of 2025, cutting 1 or 2 more times.
The ECB will cut three to four times in 2025 altogether. We think the ECB is slightly more likely to do three over four given.
commentary_higher: Concerns about remaining inflationary pressure keep interest rates high along with a reluctance on the part of the ECB to reduce rates significantly
commentary_lower: The Eurozone economy weakens significantly, requiring the ECB to move into a zone that begins to stimulate demand

commentary_central: Another one to two cuts by mid 2026 towards a neutral rate of about 2 per cent.

Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP, due to stronger public finances and lower potential growth rates. The path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario
commentary_higher: Stronger growth or a growing lack of confidence in Eurozone public finances would require a higher neutral interest rate. Strong growth because plentiful potential alternative investments allows savers to demand higher returns and weak public finances because government needs to attract more savings
commentary_lower: Weak growth and persistently low investment generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: Headline inflation has returned to target even if services inflation remains elevated, justifying a majority of the MPC to proceed with a first cut in August.
commentary_higher: The last MPC decision was 'finely balanced' and bad wage and price data could still derail an August cut
commentary_lower: Services inflation surprises to the downside, accompanied by signs of significantly weaker demand

commentary_central: The BoE pauses in September before continuing with easing later in the year
commentary_higher: the Bank of England expects services inflation to soften to 5 per cent by September. Insufficient progress towards this level could justify a majority of the MPC voting to hold rates at their current level
commentary_lower: If economic conditions deteriorate and inflation persistence fades, it is possible (though unlikely) that the MPC proceed with back to back cuts in August and September

commentary_central: We expect the BoE to make two cuts by the end of 2024 as the headline rate of inflation hovers around the two per cent target. Given adherence to fiscal rules by both major parties, we do not expect the election outcome to materially impact the path of inflation (and therefore the MPCs decision making) this year
commentary_higher: MPC members could move slower or even keep rates at the current restrictive levels if services inflation and wage pressures remain eleveated
commentary_lower: UK activity slows significantly over the final quarter of the year, requiring a more agressive programme of cuts

commentary_central: The BoE will deliver two more cuts by the middle of 2025 as inflation returns sustainably to target and wage pressures cool
commentary_higher: Persistent wage and service price pressures see rate-setters adopt a more cautious pace of easing
commentary_lower: The UK economy weakens in 2025 as the MPC stimulate demand by more rapidly lowering interest rates

commentary_central: The BoE will deliver two more cuts by end 2025 as it eases policy gradually towards a more neutral rate. Despite a later start to the cutting cycle, the BoE still delivers a total of six quarter point cuts by the end of the year
commentary_higher: Concerns about remaining inflationary pressure leaves the MPC reluctant to significantly relax its stance
commentary_lower: The UK economy weakens significantly, requiring the BoE to stimulate demand

commentary_central: The BoE will likely deliver one to two more cuts by mid-2026 as interest rates converge towards neutral levels
commentary_higher: Ongoing strong wage demands and the resulting higher demand mean fewer rate cuts from the MPC
commentary_lower: A weak economic outlook sees the MPC cut rates close to, or even below, the neutral rate

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP, due to stronger public finances and lower potential growth rates. The path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario
commentary_higher: Stronger growth or a growing lack of confidence in UK public finances would require a higher neutral interest rate. Strong growth because plentiful potential alternative investments allow savers to demand higher returns and weak public finances because government needs to attract more savings
commentary_lower: Weak growth and persistently low investment generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: The BoJ feels it has enough evidence on a positive wage price dynamic to increase rate and end negative rates but wants to tighten monetary policy slowly
commentary_higher: BoJ defends value of the yen with a rate rise despite continued weakness of its economy on fears of sustained high inflation
commentary_lower: An unlikely reaction to the weakness in the Japanese economy

commentary_central: Not firm view, by end year
commentary_higher: The BoJ worries that prolonged yen weakness will push inflation up too fast and requires a rate rise to stabilise the currency
commentary_lower: Sudden economic weakness forces the BoJ to reverse course

commentary_central: BoJ feels it is making progress normalising monetary policy amid a still relatively weak economy and inflation expectations converging on 2 per cent
commentary_higher: Ongoing strong wage demands and an economic rebound embeds inflation into expectations
commentary_lower: Signs of deflation return, significantly weaker expectations at the next round

commentary_central: BoJ feels it is making progress normalising monetary policy amid a still relatively weak economy and inflation expectations converging on 2 per cent
commentary_higher: Ongoing strong wage demands and an economic rebound embeds inflation into expectations
commentary_lower: Signs of deflation return, significantly weaker expectations at the next round

commentary_central: The BoJ delivers a cautious tightening but will still effectively zero interest rates. The tightening has been more symbolic than real or significant
commentary_higher: Japanâ€™s economy reaches lift off with positive wage expectations and a decisive break with the past
commentary_lower: The Japanese economy retains the need for negative interest rates with any move perceived to be too risky

commentary_central: The BoJ delivers a cautious tightening but will still effectively zero interest rates. The tightening has been more symbolic than real or significant
commentary_higher: Japanâ€™s economy reaches lift off with positive wage expectations and a decisive break with the past
commentary_lower: The Japanese economy retains the need for negative interest rates with any move perceived to be too risky

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a relatively low neutral rate similar to the very long term JGB yield. The rate is low given Japanâ€™s long history of difficulties in sufficiently raising inflation rates, which we expect to continue, albeit with less of a struggle than in the 2000s. The path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario
commentary_higher: A successful emergence from decades of weak growth and inflation would require higher neutral interest rates. A clear exit from below target inflation would need higher nominal rates to keep the same longer-term monetary policy stance
commentary_lower: Japan falls back into its low inflation trap, failing to generate domestic inflation and wage growth.
